overview_summary: None of the three neighboring landowners have publicly expressed a stance on the development or clean energy projects. All are categorized as unknown in their support or opposition, with no direct statements found. None holds an elected office; one (Bezon) has moderate influence through a county role and farm family ties, while the others have low community profiles.

neighbors.name: George Shamblin
neighbors.claims: George Shamblin is identified as an owner of local property (tax parcel 12.-1-58) in Genesee County assessment records ([townofoakfieldny.gov](https://townofoakfieldny.gov/#:~:text=Town%20of%20Oakfield%202024%20Final,%E2%80%93%20Click%20here%20to%20download)). No town board minutes or local news reports were found that mention Shamblin, and he does not hold any public office (the Alabama/Oakfield area is represented by other officials) ([www.geneseeny.gov](https://www.geneseeny.gov/Department-Content/Legislature/Legislative-Members#:~:text=Home%20%2F%20Legislature%2FLegislative%20Members%20,3%2C%20Towns)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach personally via a trusted fellow farmer, emphasizing that the project will not disrupt his land or daily life.

neighbors.name: Anne Bezon
neighbors.claims: Anne M. Bezon was hired in 2012 by the Genesee County Sheriff’s Office to supervise the Justice for Children Advocacy Center, bringing years of social work experience ([www.thebatavian.com](https://www.thebatavian.com/howard-owens/anne-bezon-named-supervisor-child-advocacy-center/33598#:~:text=The%20Genesee%20County%20Sheriff%E2%80%99s%20Office,Services%20counselor%20at%20the%20center)). She is a local native who graduated from Oakfield-Alabama Central School in 2004 and earned a master’s degree in social work by 2010 ([www.thebatavian.com](https://www.thebatavian.com/howard-owens/anne-bezon-named-supervisor-child-advocacy-center/33598#:~:text=The%202004%20high%20school%20alumna,2012%20class%20of%20Leadership%20Genesee)). The Bezon family is among Genesee County’s last muckland farming families, operating a 383-acre muck and upland farm (Bezon & Sons) that has persisted for three generations ([www.thebatavian.com](https://www.thebatavian.com/howard-owens/joe-bezon-has-spent-lifetime-mucking-and-he-wouldnt-have-it-any-other-way/37511#:~:text=Still%2C%20Bezon%2C%20in%20his%2075th,is%20quite%20happy%20doing%20it)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a respected local farm community member reach out, highlighting how the project honors her family’s farming legacy and provides long-term community benefits.

neighbors.name: Brian Pritchett
neighbors.claims: Brian Pritchett appears as the owner of parcel 16.-1-6 in county tax records ([townofoakfieldny.gov](https://townofoakfieldny.gov/#:~:text=Town%20of%20Oakfield%202024%20Final,%E2%80%93%20Click%20here%20to%20download)). Like Shamblin, his name does not appear in available local government listings or media archives, and he holds no known public position in the community ([www.geneseeny.gov](https://www.geneseeny.gov/Department-Content/Legislature/Legislative-Members#:~:text=Home%20%2F%20Legislature%2FLegislative%20Members%20,3%2C%20Towns)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage through mutual acquaintances in an informal setting, listening to any concerns since he has no visible public stance.
